what: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
title: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
text: Delivering type-setting equations prose plots functions statistics probability curricula

title: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
text: Mathematical fluency involves frequent use equations. However, typing equations use electronic documents can tedious. classroom setting set curriculum, set equations mastered well defined. shortcuts produce set equations prose plots beneficial students instructors alike. goal independent study create functions quickly deliver typed versions equations translate beautiful printed versions. store typed versions thoughtfully crafted R functions make typed equations easily accessible. functions bundled R package.

title: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
text: Using mathematical notation powerful way communicate probabilistic statistical concept. notation combined data visualization descriptive prose power even greater. However, using equations contexts often done typing typesetting version equation; can awkward. Consider probability density function normal distribution, centered  standard deviation :  typed version equation follows distant cousin beautiful rendered kin : p(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{ 2 \pi \sigma^2 }} e^{ - \frac{ (x - \mu)^2 } {2 \sigma^2} } Furthermore, want use annotate plot equation, need use plotmath, completely different type setting system. p(x) * {phantom() == phantom()} * frac(1, sqrt(2*pi*sigma^{2}, )) * phantom(.)*e^{phantom() - frac((x - mu)^{2}, 2*sigma^{2})}
code: library(ggplot2) ggxmean:::stamp_space() +    ggxmean::stamp_normal_dist() +   annotate(geom = "text",             label = "p(x) * {phantom() == phantom()} * frac(1, sqrt(2*pi*sigma^{2}, )) * phantom(.)*e^{phantom() - frac((x - mu)^{2}, 2*sigma^{2})} ",            parse = T,            x = 2, y = .3)

what: A different work flow within intro probability and statistics course work…
title: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
text: call function get back text render beautiful equations. example function like typeset_eq_normal() called get typed version prose stamp_eq_normal() use ggplot2. package ma206equations delivers exactly . ma206equations delivers tex version equations can used prose, shown : Educators can call equation copy paste hybrid prose-code documents, use -line code return equation dynamically: example return equation inline: use equations plotting context, ma206equations provides stamp_eq_*() functions. example print normal distribution equation ma206equations follows:
code: ma206equations::typeset_eq_normal() #> $p(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{ 2 \pi \sigma^2 }} e^{ - \frac{ (x - \mu)^2 } {2 \sigma^2} }$ This is an example of how to return an equation inline:     `r ma206equations::typeset_eq_normal(inline = TRUE)` library(ggplot2) library(ma206equations) ggxmean:::stamp_space() +    ma206equations::stamp_eq_normal(x = 2, y = .3) +    ggxmean::stamp_normal_dist()

code: # for preparation of stamp functions readLines("data-raw/plotmath_equations_template.txt") #>  [1] "# Note: do not edit .R file directly; file created from equations_temlapte.txt file" #>  [2] ""                                                                                    #>  [3] "#' function_name_from_spreadsheet"                                                   #>  [4] "#'"                                                             #>  [7] "#' @param x a numeric indicating position on x axis"                                 #>  [8] "#' @param y a numeric indicating position on y axis"                                 #>  [9] "#' @param ..."                                                                       #> [10] "#'"                                                                                  #> [11] "#' @return a ggplot2 annotation layer which is the plotmath version of a function"   #> [12] "#' @export"                                                                          #> [13] "#'"                                                                                  #> [14] "#' @examples"                                                                        #> [15] "#' library(ggplot2)"                                                                 #> [16] "#' ggplot() +"                                                                       #> [17] "#'    function_name_from_spreadsheet()"                                              #> [18] "function_name_from_spreadsheet <- function(x = 0,  y = 0, ...){"                     #> [19] ""                                                                                    #> [20] "  plotmath_input <- \"plotmath_input_from_spreadsheet\""                             #> [21] ""                                                                                    #> [22] "  ggplot2::annotate(geom = \"text\","                                                #> [23] "           label = plotmath_input,"                                                  #> [24] "           parse = T,"                                                               #> [25] "           x = x, y = y, ... )"                                                      #> [26] ""                                                                                    #> [27] "}"

title: Provide typesetting text for commonly used equations
text: Consider Ian Stewart’s poster , ‘Equations changed world.’ see equations verbal way refer equations - equation’s name. typesetting version, thankfully, appear. setting using software, might preferable refer equation name rather always typing typesetting version. example typeset_pathagoreans() return $ ^2 + b^2 = c^2 $ copy pasted used dynamically hybrid prose/code document like jupiter notebooks, rmarkdown, quarto.   ‘math symbols added, image gif surged popularity, particularly Brazilian parts social media, grew popular worldwide.’ “https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/math-lady-confused-lady” Chat GPT prompt: ‘woman says ’s 29 weeks pregnant’ meme funny? “woman says ’s 29 weeks pregnant” meme humorous observation specificity women tend describe pregnancy progress. joke woman says 29 weeks pregnant providing level detail necessary people, can seen somewhat comical. meme often features photo image person confused bewildered expression, text overlayed reads something along lines “trying figure many months .” humor comes idea can difficult people pregnant familiar pregnancy terminology understand meant phrases like “29 weeks.” short, meme funny pokes fun precision pregnant women tend describe pregnancy progress, confusion can result level detail shared others familiar terminology.
